ground_truth: Mrs. Hilbery: I m sure Mr. Denham would like to see our things, Katharine. ground_truth: Mrs. Hilbery: There are some books that _live_, They are young with us, and they grow old with us. Are you fond of poetry, Mr. Denham? But what an absurd question to ask! The truth is, dear Mr. Fortescue has almost tired me out. He is so eloquent and so witty, so searching and so profound that, after half an hour or so, I feel inclined to turn out all the lights. But perhaps he d be more wonderful than ever in the dark. What d you think, Katharine? Shall we give a little party in complete darkness? There d have to be bright rooms for the bores....

Dialogue History: Katharine Hilbery: Go on,
Ralph Denham: Of course, I don t know how you spend your time, but I suppose you have to show people round. You are writing a life of your grandfather, aren t you? And this kind of thing must take up a lot of time.
Katharine Hilbery: You ve got it very nearly right, but I only help my mother. I don t write myself.
Ralph Denham: Do you do anything yourself?
Katharine Hilbery: What do you mean? I don t leave the house at ten and come back at six.
Ralph Denham: I don t mean that.
Katharine Hilbery: Nobody ever does do anything worth doing nowadays, You see we don t even print as well as they did, and as for poets or painters or novelists there are none; so, at any rate, I m not singular.
Ralph Denham: No, we haven t any great men, I m very glad that we haven t. I hate great men. The worship of greatness in the nineteenth century seems to me to explain the worthlessness of that generation.
Mrs. Hilbery: Well, how do you like our things, Mr. Denham?
Mrs. Hilbery: There are some books that _live_, They are young with us, and they grow old with us. Are you fond of poetry, Mr. Denham? But what an absurd question to ask! The truth is, dear Mr. Fortescue has almost tired me out. He is so eloquent and so witty, so searching and so profound that, after half an hour or so, I feel inclined to turn out all the lights. ground_truth: Mrs. Hilbery: But we ve any number of things to show you! Books, pictures, china, manuscripts, and the very chair that Mary Queen of Scots sat in when she heard of Darnley s murder. I must lie down for a little, and Katharine must change her dress (though she s wearing a very pretty one), but if you don t mind being left alone, supper will be at eight. I dare say you ll write a poem of your own while you re waiting. Ah, how I love the firelight! Doesn t our room look charming?

Dialogue History: Joan: Hilda was here to-day, She brought Bobbie he s a fine boy now.
Joan: Shall you talk to mother? Because, you see, the thing s got to be settled, one way or another. Charles must write to Uncle John if he s going there.
Ralph Denham: I suppose it doesn t much matter either way, He s doomed to misery in the long run.
Joan: You know you re talking nonsense, It doesn t hurt any one to have to earn their own living. I m very glad I have to earn mine.
Ralph Denham: Isn t that only because you ve forgotten how to enjoy yourself? You never have time for anything decent
Joan: As for instance?
Ralph Denham: Well, going for walks, or music, or books, or seeing interesting people. You never do anything that s really worth doing any more than I do.
Joan: I always think you could make this room much nicer, if you liked,
Ralph Denham: What does it matter what sort of room I have when I m forced to spend all the best years of my life drawing up deeds in an office?
Joan: You said two days ago that you found the law so interesting.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Ralph Denham: So it is if one could afford to know anything about it.

I want to know, what does it mean?

ground_truth: Mrs. Hilbery: What is nobler, than to be a woman to whom every one turns, in sorrow or difficulty? How have the young women of your generation improved upon that, Katharine? I can see them now, sweeping over the lawns at Melbury House, in their flounces and furbelows, so calm and stately and imperial (and the monkey and the little black dwarf following behind), as if nothing mattered in the world but to be beautiful and kind. But they did more than we do, I sometimes think. They WERE, and that s better than doing. They seem to me like ships, like majestic ships, holding on their way, not shoving or pushing, not fretted by little things, as we are, but taking their way, like ships with white sails.

ground_truth: Mrs. Hilbery: Ah, you wretch! what a wicked old despot you were, in your day! How we all bowed down before you!  Maggie,  she used to say,  if it hadn t been for me, where would you be now?  And it was true; she brought them together, you know. She said to my father,  Marry her,  and he did; and she said to poor little Clara,  Fall down and worship him,  and she did; but she got up again, of course. What else could one expect? She was a mere child eighteen and half dead with fright, too. But that old tyrant never repented. She used to say that she had given them three perfect months, and no one had a right to more; and I sometimes think, Katharine, that s true, you know. It s more than most of us have, only we have to pretend, which was a thing neither of them could ever do. I fancy, that there was a kind of sincerity in those days between men and women which, with all your outspokenness, you haven t got.

I can see them now, sweeping over the lawns at Melbury House, in their flounces and furbelows, so calm and stately and imperial (and the monkey and the little black dwarf following behind), as if nothing mattered in the world but to be beautiful and kind. But they did more than we do, I sometimes think. They WERE, and that s better than doing. They seem to me like ships, like majestic ships, holding on their way, not shoving or pushing, not fretted by little things, as we are, but taking their way, like ships with white sails.
Mrs. Hilbery: That s Janie Mannering, I must have told you how she found her cook drunk under the kitchen table when the Empress was coming to dinner, and tucked up her velvet sleeves (she always dressed like an Empress herself), cooked the whole meal, and appeared in the drawing-room as if she d been sleeping on a bank of roses all day. Mrs. Hilbery: And that s Queenie Colquhoun, who took her coffin out with her to Jamaica, packed with lovely shawls and bonnets, because you couldn t get coffins in Jamaica, and she had a horror of dying there (as she did), and being devoured by the white ants. And that s Miriam, in her coachman s cloak, with all the little capes on, and she wore great top-boots underneath. You young people may say you re unconventional, but you re nothing compared with her.
Mrs. Hilbery: Ah, you wretch! what a wicked old despot you were, in your day! How we all bowed down before you!  Maggie,  she used to say,  if it hadn t been for me, where would you be now? She used to say that she had given them three perfect months, and no one had a right to more; and I sometimes think, Katharine, that s true, you know. It s more than most of us have, only we have to pretend, which was a thing neither of them could ever do. Some of the most terrible things in history have been done on principle,

Arthur, I confess, has always seemed to me a bit of a fop; I can t imagine how Laura married him. But you say you re a solicitor, Mr. Denham. Katharine Hilbery: Intelligent and introspective, speaking in composed, thoughtful tones, struggling between duty and desire.
Mrs. Milvain: Proper and self-satisfied, speaking in smug, knowing remarks, deeply invested in maintaining social status.
Parlor-Maid: Timid and discreet, speaking in hushed, respectful tones, careful not to overstep her place.


Dialogue History: Aunt Millicent: But you write, too?
Ralph Denham: In my spare time,
Aunt Millicent: In your spare time! That is a proof of devotion, indeed.
Aunt Millicent: Um um Pendennis Warrington I could never forgive Laura, for not marrying George, in spite of everything. George Eliot did the very same thing; and Lewes was a little frog-faced man, with the manner of a dancing master. But Warrington, now, had everything in his favor; intellect, passion, romance, distinction, and the connection was a mere piece of undergraduate folly. Arthur, I confess, has always seemed to me a bit of a fop; I can t imagine how Laura married him. But you say you re a solicitor, Mr. Denham. Now there are one or two things I should like to ask you about Shakespeare They say, nowadays, that Shakespeare was a lawyer. They say, that accounts for his knowledge of human nature. There s a fine example for you, Mr. Denham. Study your clients, young man, and the world will be the richer one of these days, I have no doubt. Tell me, how do we come out of it, now; better or worse than you expected?
Ralph Denham: Worse, Mrs. Cosham, a good deal worse. I m afraid the ordinary man is a bit of a rascal
Aunt Millicent: And the ordinary woman?
Ralph Denham: No, I don t like the ordinary woman either
Aunt Millicent: Ah, dear me, I ve no doubt that s very true, very true. Swift would have agreed with you, anyhow
Mrs. Milvain: Charles Lavington, you remember, was a solicitor, But you wouldn t remember him, Katharine.
Katharine Hilbery: Mr. Lavington? Oh, yes, I do, The summer we had a house near Tenby. I remember the field and the pond with the tadpoles, and making haystacks with Mr. Lavington.

 [/INST]

ground_truth: Mrs. Milvain: It was at Tenby that you were chased by the bull, But that you couldn t remember, though it s true you were a wonderful child. Such eyes she had, Mr. Denham! I used to say to her father,  She s watching us, and summing us all up in her little mind.  And they had a nurse in those days, who was a good woman, but engaged to a sailor. When she ought to have been attending to the baby, her eyes were on the sea. And Mrs. Hilbery allowed this girl Susan her name was to have him to stay in the village. They abused her goodness, I m sorry to say, and while they walked in the lanes, they stood the perambulator alone in a field where there was a bull. The animal became enraged by the red blanket in the perambulator, and Heaven knows what might have happened if a gentleman had not been walking by in the nick of time, and rescued Katharine in his arms!

Dialogue History: Mary Datchet: The cottage I m thinking of stands by itself in a little orchard.
Ralph Denham: And what about the Suffrage?
Mary Datchet: Oh, there are other things in the world besides the Suffrage,
Ralph Denham: D you know the points of the compass?
Mary Datchet: Well, of course, What d you take me for? a Cockney like you?
Mary Datchet: It s my native land, this, I could smell my way about it blindfold. That s Christopher, come in already, and gone to feed his chickens,
Mr. Datchet: You came by the 3.10, Mr. Denham? They treat us very well, on the whole. Considering the increase of traffic, they treat us very well indeed. I have the curiosity sometimes to count the trucks on the goods  trains, and they re well over fifty well over fifty, at this season of the year.
Elizabeth: It s not the kitchen really, but we call it so
Edward: It s the nicest room in the house,
Elizabeth: It s got the old rests by the side of the fireplace, where the men hung their guns, Show Mr. Denham the steps, Christopher.... When the Ecclesiastical Commissioners were here two years ago they said this was the most interesting part of the house. These narrow bricks prove that it is five hundred years old five hundred years, I think they may have said six.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines.

ground_truth: Ralph Denham: All this money-making and working ten hours a day in an office, what s it FOR? When one s a boy, you see, one s head is so full of dreams that it doesn t seem to matter what one does. And if you re ambitious, you re all right; you ve got a reason for going on. Now my reasons ceased to satisfy me. Perhaps I never had any. That s very likely now I come to think of it. (What reason is there for anything, though?) Still, it s impossible, after a certain age, to take oneself in satisfactorily. And I know what carried me on

ground_truth: William Rodney: You make yourself think things you don t think, Believe me, Katharine, before we came here we were perfectly happy. You were full of plans for our house the chair-covers, don t you remember? like any other woman who is about to be married. Now, for no reason whatever, you begin to fret about your feeling and about my feeling, with the usual result. I assure you, Katharine, I ve been through it all myself. At one time I was always asking myself absurd questions which came to nothing either. What you want, if I may say so, is some occupation to take you out of yourself when this morbid mood comes on. If it hadn t been for my poetry, I assure you, I should often have been very much in the same state myself. To let you into a secret, I ve often gone home from seeing you in such a state of nerves that I had to force myself to write a page or two before I could get you out of my head. Ask Denham; he ll tell you how he met me one night; he ll tell you what a state he found me in.

I believe I care for you more genuinely than nine men out of ten care for the women they re in love with. It s only a story one makes up in one s mind about another person, and one knows all the time it isn t true. Of course one knows; why, one s always taking care not to destroy the illusion. One takes care not to see them too often, or to be alone with them for too long together. It s a pleasant illusion, but if you re thinking of the risks of marriage, it seems to me that the risk of marrying a person you re in love with is something colossal.

Mary Datchet: Yes enough work to last a lifetime,
Mrs. Seal: To last a lifetime? My dear child, it will last all our lifetimes. As one falls another steps into the breach. My father, in his generation, a pioneer I, coming after him, do my little best. What, alas! can one do more? And now it s you young women we look to you the future looks to you. Ah, my dear, if I d a thousand lives, I d give them all to our cause. The cause of women, d you say? I say the cause of humanity. And there are some who don t see it! There are some who are satisfied to go on, year after year, refusing to admit the truth. And we who have the vision the kettle boiling over? No, no, let me see to it we who know the truth,
Mrs. Seal: It s all so _simple_.
Mrs. Seal: One would have thought, that men of University training, like Mr. Asquith one would have thought that an appeal to reason would not be unheard by them. But reason, what is reason without Reality?
Mr. Clacton: But, Mrs. Seal, we have to aim at a judicious combination of the two,
Mr. Clacton: Reality has to be voiced by reason before it can make itself felt. The weak point of all these movements, Miss Datchet, is that they are not based upon sufficiently intellectual grounds. A mistake, in my opinion. The British public likes a pellet of reason in its jam of eloquence a pill of reason in its pudding of sentiment,
Mary Datchet: Look, Sally, these letters want copying. These I ve not looked at. The question of the new census will have to be gone into carefully. But I m going home now. Good night, Mr. Clacton; good night, Sally.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]

ground_truth: Ralph Denham: You say that we ve got to be honest, Very well. I will try to tell you the facts; but I warn you, you ll think me mad. It s a fact, though, that since I first saw you four or five months ago I have made you, in an utterly absurd way, I expect, my ideal. I m almost ashamed to tell you what lengths I ve gone to. It s become the thing that matters most in my life. Without knowing you, except that you re beautiful, and all that, I ve come to believe that we re in some sort of agreement; that we re after something together; that we see something.... I ve got into the habit of imagining you; I m always thinking what you d say or do; I walk along the street talking to you; I dream of you. It s merely a bad habit, a schoolboy habit, day-dreaming; it s a common experience; half one s friends do the same; well, those are the facts.

Ralph Denham: Ambitious and restless, speaking in intense, searching phrases, constantly questioning his place in the world.
William Rodney: Pompous and insecure, speaking in overly formal, self-important tones, desperate for validation.


Dialogue History: Ralph Denham: I have not spoken a word to you that I do not mean,
Katharine Hilbery: Tell me then what it is that you mean,
Ralph Denham: You say that we ve got to be honest, Very well. I will try to tell you the facts; but I warn you, you ll think me mad. It s a fact, though, that since I first saw you four or five months ago I have made you, in an utterly absurd way, I expect, my ideal. I m almost ashamed to tell you what lengths I ve gone to. It s become the thing that matters most in my life. Without knowing you, except that you re beautiful, and all that, I ve come to believe that we re in some sort of agreement; that we re after something together; that we see something.... I ve got into the habit of imagining you; I m always thinking what you d say or do; I walk along the street talking to you; I dream of you. It s merely a bad habit, a schoolboy habit, day-dreaming; it s a common experience; half one s friends do the same; well, those are the facts.
Katharine Hilbery: If you were to know me you would feel none of this,
Katharine Hilbery: We don t know each other we ve always been interrupted.... Were you going to tell me this that day my aunts came?
Ralph Denham: The day you told me of your engagement,
Ralph Denham: I deny that I should cease to feel this if I knew you,
Ralph Denham: I should feel it more reasonably that s all. I shouldn t talk the kind of nonsense I ve talked to-night.... But it wasn t nonsense. It was the truth,
Ralph Denham: It s the important thing. You can force me to talk as if this feeling for you were an hallucination, but all our feelings are that. The best of them are half illusions. Still, if it weren t as real a feeling as I m capable of, I shouldn t be changing my life on your account.
Katharine Hilbery: What do you mean?

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Ralph Denham: I told you. I m taking a cottage. I m giving up my profession.

ground_truth: Mrs. Hilbery: My dear, I m not talking about _your_ William, though that s another reason for liking him. I m talking, I m thinking, I m dreaming of _my_ William William Shakespeare, of course. Isn t it odd, that for all one can see, that dear old thing in the blue bonnet, crossing the road with her basket on her arm, has never heard that there was such a person? Yet it all goes on: lawyers hurrying to their work, cabmen squabbling for their fares, little boys rolling their hoops, little girls throwing bread to the gulls, as if there weren t a Shakespeare in the world. I should like to stand at that crossing all day long and say:  People, read Shakespeare!

ground_truth: Mrs. Hilbery: Katharine! I ve hit upon a brilliant idea! to lay out, say, a hundred pounds or so on copies of Shakespeare, and give them to working men. Some of your clever friends who get up meetings might help us, Katharine. And that might lead to a playhouse, where we could all take parts. You d be Rosalind but you ve a dash of the old nurse in you. Your father s Hamlet, come to years of discretion; and I m well, I m a bit of them all; I m quite a large bit of the fool, but the fools in Shakespeare say all the clever things. Now who shall William be? A hero? Hotspur? Henry the Fifth? No, William s got a touch of Hamlet in him, too. I can fancy that William talks to himself when he s alone. Ah, Katharine, you must say very beautiful things when you re together!

Katharine Hilbery: Intelligent and introspective, speaking in composed, thoughtful tones, struggling between duty and desire.
Mrs. Bankes: Sociable and sharp-tongued, speaking in animated, gossipy phrases, always up to date on the latest news.


Dialogue History: Mrs. Hilbery: It won t seem to you nonsense in ten years  time,
Mrs. Hilbery: Believe me, Katharine, you ll look back on these days afterwards; you ll remember all the silly things you ve said; and you ll find that your life has been built on them. The best of life is built on what we say when we re in love. It isn t nonsense, Katharine, it s the truth, it s the only truth.
Katharine Hilbery: Mary Datchet,
Mrs. Hilbery: Ah I half wish I d called you Mary, but it wouldn t have gone with Hilbery, and it wouldn t have gone with Rodney. Now this isn t the passage I wanted. (I never can find what I want.) But it s spring; it s the daffodils; it s the green fields; it s the birds.
Mrs. Hilbery: My dear child, how odious the triumphs of science are! They ll be linking us with the moon next but who was that?
Katharine Hilbery: William,
Mrs. Hilbery: I ll forgive William anything, for I m certain that there aren t any Williams in the moon. I hope he s coming to luncheon?
Katharine Hilbery: He s coming to tea.
Mrs. Hilbery: Well, that s better than nothing, and I promise to leave you alone.
Katharine Hilbery: There s no need for you to do that,

ground_truth: Katharine Hilbery: My father and mother were in Italy, and something happened so that I couldn t join them. For three weeks I lived entirely by myself, and the only person I spoke to was a stranger in a shop where I lunched a man with a beard. Then I went back to my room by myself and well, I did what I liked. It doesn t make me out an amiable character, I m afraid, but I can t endure living with other people. An occasional man with a beard is interesting; he s detached; he lets me go my way, and we know we shall never meet again. Therefore, we are perfectly sincere a thing not possible with one s friends.

ground_truth: Mr. Basnett: In starting a society such as we wish to start (we can t say any more at present), there are two things to remember the Press and the public. Other societies, which shall be nameless, have gone under because they ve appealed only to cranks. If you don t want a mutual admiration society, which dies as soon as you ve all discovered each other s faults, you must nobble the Press. You must appeal to the public.

Dialogue History: Ralph Denham: I don t want it,
Mary Datchet: Well, you know best,
Ralph Denham: Mary, I m a brute! Here I come and waste your time, and do nothing but make myself disagreeable.
Mary Datchet: A cold coming on does make one feel wretched,
Ralph Denham: I ve not got a cold. That was a lie. There s nothing the matter with me. I m mad, I suppose. I ought to have had the decency to keep away. But I wanted to see you I wanted to tell you I m in love, Mary.
Mary Datchet: In love, are you? I m glad, Ralph.
Ralph Denham: I suppose I m in love. Anyhow, I m out of my mind. I can t think, I can t work, I don t care a hang for anything in the world. Good Heavens, Mary! I m in torment! One moment I m happy; next I m miserable. I hate her for half an hour; then I d give my whole life to be with her for ten minutes; all the time I don t know what I feel, or why I feel it; it s insanity, and yet it s perfectly reasonable. Can you make any sense of it? Can you see what s happened? I m raving, I know; don t listen, Mary; go on with your work.
Mary Datchet: Do sit down, You make me so
Mary Datchet: You haven t told me her name you d rather not, I suppose?
Ralph Denham: Her name? Katharine Hilbery.

ground_truth: Katharine Hilbery: But then, you knew you were in love; but we re different. At the same time, we can t live without each other, because

ground_truth: Mrs. Hilbery: I hope you re not disposing of somebody s fortune in a hurry, or cutting off an entail at one blow, because I want to ask you to do me a favor. And Anderson won t keep his horse waiting. (Anderson is a perfect tyrant, but he drove my dear father to the Abbey the day they buried him.) I made bold to come to you, Mr. Denham, not exactly in search of legal assistance (though I don t know who I d rather come to, if I were in trouble), but in order to ask your help in settling some tiresome little domestic affairs that have arisen in my absence. I ve been to Stratford-on-Avon (I must tell you all about that one of these days), and there I got a letter from my sister-in-law, a dear kind goose who likes interfering with other people s children because she s got none of her own. (We re dreadfully afraid that she s going to lose the sight of one of her eyes, and I always feel that our physical ailments are so apt to turn into mental ailments. I think Matthew Arnold says something of the same kind about Lord Byron.) But that s neither here nor there.
